facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 52 of 1954 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by this Court on the 25th January, 1954, from Judgment and Order dated the 23rd May, 1953, of the Election Tribunal, Himachal Pradesh, Simla, in Election Petition No. 14 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by Supreme Court on 25th January 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by this Court on the 25th January, 1954, from Judgment and Order dated the 23rd May, 1953, of the Election Tribunal, Himachal Pradesh, Simla, in Election Petition No. 14 of 1952.

facts.text: Election Tribunal, Himachal Pradesh, Simla passed Judgment and Order dated 23rd May 1953 in Election Petition No. 14 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by this Court on the 25th January, 1954, from Judgment and Order dated the 23rd May, 1953, of the Election Tribunal, Himachal Pradesh, Simla, in Election Petition No. 14 of 1952.

facts.text: Five candidates (respondents 1 to 5) were nominated on 12th October 1951 for election to Legislative Assembly of Himachal Pradesh for Rohru Constituency in Mahasu District.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal against the order of the Election Tribunal, Himachal Pradesh, dismissing Election Petition No. 14 of 1952. On 12th October, 1951, five candidates  respondents 1 to 5 herein  were duly nominated for election to the Legislative Assembly of the State of Himachal Pradesh for the Rohru Constituency in Mahasu District.

facts.text: Polling took place on 23rd November 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The polling took place on 23rd November, 1951, and on 30th November, 195 1, the first respondent was declared elected, he having secured the largest number of votes.

facts.text: First respondent declared elected on 30th November 1951, having secured largest number of votes.

anchor.surface_text: The polling took place on 23rd November, 1951, and on 30th November, 195 1, the first respondent was declared elected, he having secured the largest number of votes.

facts.text: Election result published in Official Gazette on 20th December 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The result was published in the Official Gazette on 20th December, 1951. On 14th February, 1952, one of the unsuccessful candidates, Gyan Singh,  fifth respondent herein  filed Election Petition No. 14 of 1952 challenging the validity of the election of the first respondent.

facts.text: Gyan Singh (fifth respondent) filed Election Petition No. 14 of 1952 on 14th February 1952 challenging election of first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The result was published in the Official Gazette on 20th December, 1951. On 14th February, 1952, one of the unsuccessful candidates, Gyan Singh,  fifth respondent herein  filed Election Petition No. 14 of 1952 challenging the validity of the election of the first respondent.

facts.text: Gyan Singh applied to withdraw petition on 4th August 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On 4th August, 1952, he applied to withdraw from the petition, and that was permitted by an order of the Tribunal dated 20th September, 1952.

facts.text: Election Tribunal permitted withdrawal on 20th September 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On 4th August, 1952, he applied to withdraw from the petition, and that was permitted by an order of the Tribunal dated 20th September, 1952.

facts.text: Appellant (elector in Rohru Constituency) brought on record as petitioner on 21st November 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, who is one of the electors in the Rohru Constituency, then applied to be brought on record as the petitioner, and that was ordered on 21st November, 1952.

facts.text: Petition challenged on grounds: Sri Padam Dev had contracts for Ayurvedic medicines, disqualified under s7(d) Act XLIII 1951; procured assistance of govt servants contravening s123(8).

anchor.surface_text: Though a number of charges were pressed -at the trial, only two of them are material for the purpose of the present appeal  1  that Sri Padam Dev was interested in contracts for the supply of Ayurvedic medicines to the Government, and was therefore disqualified for being chosen to the Assembly under section 7 d  of Act No. XLIII of 1951 and  2  that he had procured the assistance of Government servants for the furtherance of his election prospects, and had thereby contravened section 123 8  of that Act.

facts.text: Daulataram (govt servant in post office) subscribed as proposer in nomination paper of Sri Padam Dev.

anchor.surface_text: The facts giving rise to this contention were that one Daulataram had subscribed in the nomination paper of Sri Padam Dev as proposer and one Motiram as seconder, both of them being Government servants employed in the post office,

facts.text: Motiram (govt servant in post office) subscribed as seconder in nomination paper of Sri Padam Dev.

anchor.surface_text: The facts giving rise to this contention were that one Daulataram had subscribed in the nomination paper of Sri Padam Dev as proposer and one Motiram as seconder, both of them being Government servants employed in the post office,

facts.text: Sital Singh (extra-departmental agent, govt servant) appointed by Sri Padam Dev as polling agent at Arhal booth.

anchor.surface_text: and,that one Sital Singh, an extra-departmental agent, was appointed by Sri Padam Dev as one of his polling agents at a booth at Arhal.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held by judgment dated 25th September 1953 that s7(d) not applicable to Part C States and no proof of subsisting contracts on 12 Oct 1951; dismissed petition.

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated 25th September, 1953, the Election Tribunal held firstly that section 7 d  of Act No. XLIII of 1951 had not been made applicable to elections in Part C States, and that further there was no proof that on 12th October, 1951, the date of nomination, there were contracts subsisting between Sri Padam Dev and the Government.

facts.text: Himachal Pradesh is a Part C State.

anchor.surface_text: which governs elections to the Legislative Assemblies in Part C States.

facts.text: Mandi contract: goods supplied and price received in September 1951.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the Mandi contract the finding is that goods had been supplied and price received in September, 1951.

facts.text: Mahasu contract: Government placed order on 19th November 1951, goods supplied Dec 1951-Jan 1952.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the Mahasu contract, the Government placed the order with the respondent on 19th November, 195 1, and the goods were supplied in December, 1951, and January, 1952.

facts.text: Sirmur contract: order placed by Government on 25th September 1951, goods supplied on 1st December 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It was on the Sirmur contract that the appellant laid the greatest emphasis. In this case, the order was placed by the Government on 25th September, 1951, and the goods were actually supplied on 1st December, 1951.

facts.text: Appellant before Tribunal admitted material date for contracts was 12th October 1951 (nomination date).

anchor.surface_text: It must be mentioned that the stand taken by the appellant himself before the Tribunal was that the crucial date for determining whether there was a subsisting contract was 12th October, 1951, the date of nomination,

facts.text: Sital Singh did nothing beyond acting as polling agent.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the finding is that beyond acting as polling agent Sital Singh did nothing.

facts.text: No finding that respondent availed Sital Singh's presence to further election prospects.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is there any finding that the respondent in any manner availed himself of his presence at the polling booth to further his own election prospects.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Thus there are no grounds for holding that section 123 8  had been contravened.

issues.text: The first question that arises for determination is whether Sri Padam Dev was disqualified for being chosen to the Legislative Assembly by reason of his having held at the material dates contracts for the supply of Ayurvedic medicines to the Himachal Pradesh State Government

anchor.surface_text: The first question that arises for determination is whether Sri Padam Dev was disqualified for being chosen to the Legislative Assembly by reason of his having held at the material dates contracts for the supply of Ayurvedic medicines to the Himachal Pradesh State Government.

issues.text: It remains to consider the contention that Sri Padam Dev had procured the assistance of Government servants, and had thereby brought himself within the mischief of section 123 8

anchor.surface_text: It remains to consider the contention that Sri Padam Dev had procured the assistance of Government servants, and had thereby brought himself within the mischief of section 123 8 . The main objection before the Tribunal under this heading related to the subscribing of the nomination paper by Daulataram as proposer and Motiram as seconder.

issues.text: This question has since been decided adversely to the appellant in a recent decision of this Court reported in Rai Krushna Bose v. Binod Kanungo , where it was held that section 33 2

anchor.surface_text: This question has since been decided adversely to the appellant in a recent decision of this Court reported in Rai Krushna Bose v. Binod Kanungo  2 , where it was held that section 33  2  conferred the privilege of proposing or seconding a candidate on any person who was registered in the electoral roll, and that section 123  8  could no be construed as taking away that privilege.

issues.text: Then there is the question whether the appointment of Sital Singh as polling agent contravened section 123 8

anchor.surface_text: Then there is the question whether the appointment of Sital Singh as polling agent contravened section 123 8 . The majority of the Tribunal was of the opinion that the appointment of a Government servant as polling agent was no by itself objectionable, but the third member thought otherwise.

issues.text: the question which we have got to decide is whether as an abstract proposition of law the mere appointment of a Government servant as a polling agent is in itself and without more an infringement of section 123 8

anchor.surface_text: the question which we have got to decide is whether as an abstract proposition of law the mere appointment of a Government servant as a polling agent is in itself and without more an infringement of section 123 8 . Our answer is in the negative.

holdings.text: The disqualifications laid down in section 7 of Act No. XLIII of 1951 must be held to be comprised within section 17 of Act No. XLIX of 1951 for elections to Legislative Assemblies in Part C States.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the disqualifications laid down in section 7 of Act No. XLIII of 1951 must be held to be comprised within section 17 of the Act. It was then contended that even on the footing that section 7 of Act No. XLIII of 1951 was comprised in section 17 of Act No. XLIX of 195 1,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 17 incorporates Article 102(1)(e) referencing parliamentary laws like s7(d); scheme of Act XLIX covers qualifications/disqualifications in ss6-17 without needing to extend Part II via s8; harmonious construction avoids repugnancy.

holdings.text: Contracts with Part C States are not contracts with the Central Government, which is the appropriate government under s7(d) read with s9(1)(a) for disqualification via s17.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, there is no basis for the contention that contracts with Part C States are to be construed as contracts with the Central Government. Nor has the appellant established as a fact that there were any contracts between Sri Padam Dev and the Central Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Part C States administered by President via Chief Commissioner under Art239, distinct from Central Govt; executive action in name of Chief Commissioner per s38(2) Act XLIX, not President per Art77.

holdings.text: Sri Padam Dev held no subsisting contracts with the appropriate government on the material date of nomination (12th October 1951).

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the Mandi contract the finding is that goods had been supplied and price received in September, 1951. As regards the Mahasu contract, the Government placed the order with the respondent on 19th November, 195 1, and the goods were supplied in December, 1951, and January, 1952.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts tribunal findings on specific contracts (Mandi completed Sep; Mahasu post-nomination; Sirmur supply Dec1); appellant admitted nomination date as crucial and bound thereby; tribunal legal errors immaterial.

holdings.text: Subscribing nomination paper as proposer or seconder by government servants does not contravene s123(8).

anchor.surface_text: This question has since been decided adversely to the appellant in a recent decision of this Court reported in Rai Krushna Bose v. Binod Kanungo  2 , where it was held that section 33  2  conferred the privilege of proposing or seconding a candidate on any person who was registered in the electoral roll,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s33(2) confers privilege on registered electors; s123(8) does not abrogate it; follows binding precedent Rai Krushna Bose v. Binod Kanungo.

holdings.text: The mere appointment of a government servant as polling agent is not in itself and without more an infringement of s123(8).

anchor.surface_text: the question which we have got to decide is whether as an abstract proposition of law the mere appointment of a Government servant as a polling agent is in itself and without more an infringement of section 123  8 . Our answer is in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s46 permits appointment of polling agents without barring govt servants; analogous to s33(2) privilege; duties (identifying voters per s128) do not per se further prospects; no exploitation proved.

holdings.text: No assistance procured from government servants beyond permitted acts; s123(8) not contravened in facts.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the finding is that beyond acting as polling agent Sital Singh did nothing. Nor is there any finding that the respondent in any manner availed himself of his presence at the polling booth to further his own election prospects. Thus there are no grounds for holding that section 123 8  had been contravened.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence Daulatram/Motiram did more than propose/seconder; Sital Singh only acted as agent without exploitation for prospects.

anchor.surface_text: Chatturbhuj Vithaldas v. Moreshwar Parashram Then again, the Tribunal proceeds on the view that a candidate would be disqualified only if there was a contract subsisting at the date of the nomination.

precedents.cited_proposition: a contract is subsisting even if goods delivered but price unpaid

anchor.surface_text: Chatturbhuj Vithaldas v. Moreshwar Parashram 1  that the disqualifications would apply during the whole of the period commencing with the nomination and ending with the declaration of the election.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the disqualifications laid down in section 7 of Act No. XLIII of 1951 must be held to be comprised within section 17 of the Act. In the present case, the finding is that beyond acting as polling agent Sital Singh did numberhing. Thus there are no grounds for holding that section 123 8  had been companytravened.

Thus, there is no basis for the contention that contracts with Part C States are to be construed as contracts with the Central Government. Nor has the appellant established as a fact that there were any contracts between Sri Padam Dev and the Central Government.

In the present case, the finding is that beyond acting as polling agent Sital Singh did numberhing. Nor is there any finding that the respondent in any manner availed himself of his presence at the polling booth to further his own election prospects. Thus there are no grounds for holding that section 123 8  had been companytravened.

With reference to the Mandi contract the finding is that goods had been supplied and price received in September, 1951. As regards the Mahasu contract, the Government placed the order with the respondent on 19th November, 195 1, and the goods were supplied in December, 1951, and January, 1952.

In the present case, the finding is that beyond acting as polling agent Sital Singh did numberhing. Nor is there any finding that the respondent in any manner availed himself of his presence at the polling booth to further his own election prospects. Thus there are no grounds for holding that section 123 8  had been companytravened.

anchor.surface_text: the question which we have got to decide is whether as an abstract proposition of law the mere appointment of a Government servant as a polling agent is in itself and without more an infringement of section 123  8 . Our answer is in the negative.

In the present case, the finding is that beyond acting as polling agent Sital Singh did numberhing. Nor is there any finding that the respondent in any manner availed himself of his presence at the polling booth to further his own election prospects. Thus there are no grounds for holding that section 123 8  had been companytravened.
